ticket.title: sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them
ticket.original-body:
example migrations: @@@ ruby class M1 < ActiveRecord::Migration def self.up create_table 'users' do |t| t.string 'name' t.decimal 'v1', :precision => 10, :scale => 3 end end
def self.down drop_table 'users' end end
class M2 < ActiveRecord::Migration def self.up change_column :users, :v1, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end
def self.down end end @@@
expected resulting schema: @@@ ruby ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1", :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end end @@@
actual resulting schema: @@@ ruby ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1" end end @@@
ticket.latest-body:
example migrations: @@@ ruby class M1 < ActiveRecord::Migration def self.up create_table 'users' do |t| t.string 'name' t.decimal 'v1', :precision => 10, :scale => 3 end end
def self.down drop_table 'users' end end
class M2 < ActiveRecord::Migration def self.up change_column :users, :v1, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end
def self.down end end @@@
expected resulting schema: @@@ ruby ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1", :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end end @@@
actual resulting schema: @@@ ruby ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1" end end @@@
ticket.original-body-html:
example migrations:


class M1 < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    create_table 'users' do |t|
      t.string 'name'
      t.decimal 'v1', :precision => 10, :scale => 3
    end
  end

  def self.down
    drop_table 'users'
  end
end

class M2 < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    change_column :users, :v1, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5
  end

  def self.down
  end
end

expected resulting schema:


ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do
  create_table "users", :force => true do |t|
    t.string  "name"
    t.decimal "v1",   :precision => 12, :scale => 5
  end
end

actual resulting schema:


ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do
  create_table "users", :force => true do |t|
    t.string  "name"
    t.decimal "v1"
  end
end

version.body:
example migrations: @@@ ruby class M1 < ActiveRecord::Migration def self.up create_table 'users' do |t| t.string 'name' t.decimal 'v1', :precision => 10, :scale => 3 end end
def self.down drop_table 'users' end end
class M2 < ActiveRecord::Migration def self.up change_column :users, :v1, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end
def self.down end end @@@
expected resulting schema: @@@ ruby ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1", :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end end @@@
actual resulting schema: @@@ ruby ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1" end end @@@
version.body-html:
example migrations:

class M1 < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up







create_table 'users' do |t|
  t.string 'name'
  t.decimal 'v1', :precision => 10, :scale => 3
end





  end



  def self.down


drop_table 'users'





  end
end



class M2 < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up


change_column :users, :v1, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5





  end



  def self.down
  end
end

expected resulting schema:

ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do
  create_table "users", :force => true do |t|







t.string  "name"
t.decimal "v1",   :precision => 12, :scale => 5





  end
end

actual resulting schema:

ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do
  create_table "users", :force => true do |t|







t.string  "name"
t.decimal "v1"





  end
end
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body: I've hit this problem too. Looking into the sqlite adaptor code, you can see that it's simply dropping any+all options.
version.body-html:
I've hit this problem too.
Looking into the sqlite adaptor code, you can see that it's simply dropping any+all options.
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body: Any chance I could get you to include a new test case for this?
version.body-html: Any chance I could get you to include a new test case for this?
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body: Here's a test case that fails without the above patch and passes when it is applied. It tests that you can use change_column to alter a column's scale and precision. The attributes are dropped in the code without this patch, and they are properly changed when it is applied.
version.body-html: Here's a test case that fails without the above patch and passes when it is applied. It tests that you can use change_column to alter a column's scale and precision. The attributes are dropped in the code without this patch, and they are properly changed when it is applied.
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body:
Ok, when I click on Paul's patch I get some sort of key error, so here's my own patch that includes a test that fails with the current Rails code, as well as Adnrey's code - which makes it pass.
Note - I've made the test-case specific to sqlite3 as that's where the issue is located.
version.body-html:
Ok, when I click on Paul's patch I get some sort of key error, so here's my own patch that includes a test that fails with the current Rails code, as well as Adnrey's code - which makes it pass.

Note - I've made the test-case specific to sqlite3 as that's where the issue is located.
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body: I meant to add... but technically the test should pass on all adapters. Only I can't test Postgres - because I don't have that installed. it runs fine for all the other standard adapters ie it doesn't fail when I remove the adapter-check line except for the postgres section which doesn't run at all.
version.body-html:
I meant to add... but technically the test should pass on all adapters. Only I can't test Postgres - because I don't have that installed.
it runs fine for all the other standard adapters ie it doesn't fail when I remove the adapter-check line except for the postgres section which doesn't run at all.
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body:
Ok - that's weird. Looks like running a migration with this sets the local values for precision/scale... but doesn't actually change the real db properly. You can test that with a migration that changes *two* columns' precisions:
class M£ < ActiveRecord::Migration def self.up change_column :users, :v1, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5 change_column :users, :v2, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end
def self.down end end
expected resulting schema:
ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1", :precision => 12, :scale => 5 t.decimal "v2", :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end end
actual resulting schema:
ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1" t.decimal "v2", :precision => 12, :scale => 5 end end
If you reverse the order of two change_column names in the migration... you get:
ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do create_table "users", :force => true do |t| t.string "name" t.decimal "v1", :precision => 12, :scale => 5 t.decimal "v2" end end
ie - only the last migration seems to actually change the schema...
version.body-html:
Ok - that's weird. Looks like running a migration with this sets the local values for precision/scale... but doesn't actually change the real db properly.
You can test that with a migration that changes two columns' precisions:

class M£ < ActiveRecord::Migration
def self.up

change_column :users, :v1, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5
change_column :users, :v2, :decimal, :precision => 12, :scale => 5

end

def self.down end end

expected resulting schema:

ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do
create_table "users", :force => true do |t|

t.string  "name"
t.decimal "v1",   :precision => 12, :scale => 5
t.decimal "v2",   :precision => 12, :scale => 5

end end

actual resulting schema:

ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do
create_table "users", :force => true do |t|

t.string  "name"
t.decimal "v1"
t.decimal "v2",   :precision => 12, :scale => 5

end end

If you reverse the order of two change_column names in the migration... you get:

ActiveRecord::Schema.define(:version => 20090706090649) do
create_table "users", :force => true do |t|

t.string  "name"
t.decimal "v1",   :precision => 12, :scale => 5
t.decimal "v2"

end end

ie - only the last migration seems to actually change the schema...
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body: hmmm... and "edit last comment" feature would be appreciated.. ;)
version.body-html: hmmm... and "edit last comment" feature would be appreciated.. ;)
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body:
Hokay... so after much digging there is one important fact we need to remember. SQLite doesn't actually (natively) support :precision/scale.
The troubles that my company ran into were more based on the fact that in doing the migration... the schema lost the precision/scale - which means that when we uploaded into a NON-sqlite instance of the db... we then ran into issues.
I'm not sure how to test for this as we don't have Rails tests (that I see) where we dump the schema from one adaptor, then try to schema:load into another.
In any case, I ran across one other place where the precision/scale are "lost" in the sqlite adaptor... adding the following patch seemed to solve that... but I can't officially test it.
Any comments/suggestions welcome.
version.body-html:
Hokay... so after much digging there is one important fact we need to remember.
SQLite doesn't actually (natively) support :precision/scale.

The troubles that my company ran into were more based on the fact that in doing the migration... the schema lost the precision/scale - which means that when we uploaded into a NON-sqlite instance of the db... we then ran into issues.

I'm not sure how to test for this as we don't have Rails tests (that I see) where we dump the schema from one adaptor, then try to schema:load into another.

In any case, I ran across one other place where the precision/scale are "lost" in the sqlite adaptor... adding the following patch seemed to solve that... but I can't officially test it.

Any comments/suggestions welcome.
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body: So if I understand this correctly, the schema should retain the precision and scale, but the sqlite3 adapter should ignore it when creating the columns, correct?
version.body-html: So if I understand this correctly, the schema should retain the precision and scale, but the sqlite3 adapter should ignore it when creating the columns, correct?
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body: I've ran into this as well. Yes, it would be nice for the schema to retain the precision and scale for when we actually load it on a production database.
version.body-html: I've ran into this as well. Yes, it would be nice for the schema to retain the precision and scale for when we actually load it on a production database.
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body: I think it's more than nice, it's required. The recommendation to load from schema rather than running thru the migrations on a production deploy or any new instance deploy makes this pretty high priority.
version.body-html: I think it's more than nice, it's required. The recommendation to load from schema rather than running thru the migrations on a production deploy or any new instance deploy makes this pretty high priority.
version.tag: activerecord active_record migrations patch schema sqlite3
version.title: [PATCH] sqlite3 adapter drops :decimal columns precision & scale when migration tries to alter them

version.body:
Matt - yep - that's the ticket. The patches I've submitted do this now.
We ran into the issue because during testing we used Sqlite - but production (of course) is on a real db... and loading the schema started causing all sorts of truncation errors in our money columns :P
version.body-html:
Matt - yep - that's the ticket.
The patches I've submitted do this now.

We ran into the issue because during testing we used Sqlite - but production (of course) is on a real db... and loading the schema started causing all sorts of truncation errors in our money columns :P
